D1.title: Designing a Mission-Aligned Seminar
D1.narrative: You are preparing an upper-level interdisciplinary seminar at Soka University of America. Students already arrive with AI habits for brainstorming, translation, and writing. As you outline the syllabus, you consider how each possible stance on AI could cultivate SUA's values—leaders of humanism, intercultural dialogue, and pacifism, and graduates committed to living contributive lives. Where will you begin?

P1.narrative: You draft your new course policy: "AI-generated text is not permitted on any assignments." You frame it as protecting academic honesty and human dignity, pointing to SUA's commitment to uphold human rights. Students nod, though one asks privately if translation tools count.

P2A.narrative: A multilingual student confides: "I only use AI to translate readings so I can understand class discussion." You reaffirm your rule: each student should rely on their own effort to develop language skills. You remind yourself the policy safeguards fairness, yet you wonder how it aligns with SUA's call to foster leaders of humanism. Participation drops, and you sense growing distance.

B1.title: Designing the New Course
B1.narrative: You're drafting a syllabus for a new upper-level interdisciplinary seminar at Soka University of America. You know that students already use AI for translation, brainstorming, and writing support. Rather than ban it, you design a short unit on "Responsible AI Use" that ties directly to SUA's value of fostering leaders of humanism who can engage difference with empathy. Students will practice writing with and without AI, comparing their processes and reflecting on what they learn.

B2A.title: Ethical AI Workshops
B2A.narrative: Week three. Students bring examples of AI output alongside their own writing. They identify what AI captures — and what it misses. Discussion turns lively: "How do we know when AI's help becomes substitution?" You surface SUA's mission and values, asking which uses cultivate leaders of culture in the community. You realize they're not just learning writing — they're learning judgment.

B3A.title: Refining the Policy
B3A.narrative: Together, the class revises its "AI Use Agreement." Students agree to cite AI assistance, reflect on their process, and take responsibility for final ideas. You highlight alignment with SUA's aim to foster leaders of culture who act with integrity. You notice improved confidence in emerging writers and fewer integrity concerns. Still, updating and clarifying the policy each semester takes time. Some colleagues worry: "Won't this gray area confuse students?"

B4.title: Outcome: Ethical Clarity Through Dialogue
B4.narrative: By term's end, students submit reflective essays describing how AI shaped their thinking. Most express gratitude for being trusted to decide responsibly. A few still wish for simpler rules, but many highlight new awareness: "I learned not just what AI can do — but what I can do with it." You guide them to name which SUA values their choices advanced: humanism, culture, pacifism, or contributive lives. You sense the course has fostered something deeper than compliance: wisdom linked to mission.

E1.title: Rethinking the Assignment
E1.narrative: You sit at your desk drafting the syllabus for your new upper-level interdisciplinary course. You know students already use AI for brainstorming and translation. Instead of policing that reality, you wonder: "What if I invited AI use as part of the process itself?" You rewrite a major paper assignment into an "AI-Reflection Portfolio," where students must document prompts, evaluate AI output, and annotate what they learned about thinking itself. You frame the experiment as cultivating leaders of pacifism who can resolve complex problems with creativity and care.
